awd_titl_txt: Enzymatic Mechanism of Oxalate Decarboxylase Revealed by Biophysical and Structural Studies
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Alexander Angerhofer from the University of Florida to investigate the degradation of oxalic acid by an enzyme known as oxalate decarboxylase which is found in soil bacteria and fungi. Overloading the body with oxalic acid can lead to kidney stones and other adverse health effects in animals and humans. As a plant product oxalic acid is present in many plant-derived foods in appreciable quantities. A way to keep the amount of oxalic acid low is to decompose it by chemical reactions catalyzed by enzymes.  The research of Dr. Angerhofer is focused on the elucidation of the mechanism by which the enzyme oxalate decarboxylase breaks down oxalic acid. More specifically, Dr. Angerhofer will test the hypothesis that to decompose oxalic acid, this protein transfers electrons over a long distance, about 2 nm, between two manganese ions, one of which is located at the active site for the chemical transformation of oxalic acid.  This study will involve use of a combination of advanced biochemical methods of protein engineering with structural and spectroscopic methods, including X-ray crystallography, electron paramagnetic resonance, and optical spectroscopy. The results of this research will enhance our fundamental knowledge of reactions that involve bio-active manganese and will ultimately aid in devising strategies to mitigate the presence of oxalic acid in plants. The project supports the training of a growing and diverse science and technology workforce in the state of Florida by involving students in research that helps them acquire scientific and professional skills useful in the bio-economy of the 21st century. The training of undergraduate students is supported through a course-based undergraduate research experience at the University of Florida and through the University Research Scholars Program, which brings gifted freshmen students to the cutting edge of modern research.

This award supports the research of Dr. Angerhofer focused on the study of the molecular mechanisms by which the bacterial enzyme oxalate decarboxylase catalyzes the cleavage of the kinetically inert carbon-carbon bond in oxalic acid. It has been proposed that long-range electron transfer between the manganese ions situated at the N- and the C-terminal ends of the proteins subunits plays an important catalytic role.   X-ray crystallography, molecular dynamics simulations, electrochemistry, and an array of advanced electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) technologies, in combination with site-directed mutagenesis will be applied to the problem. The activity of manganese ions in the protein and a chain of electron transfer-active amino acids will be studied. Genetic code expansion methods will be used to introduce unnatural amino acids into the enzyme at specific target sites where they can be used to probe a long-range electron transfer pathway that may exist in the quaternary structure of the enzyme. The planned experiments will yield important structural and kinetic information about substrate and oxygen co-factor binding to the enzyme.  The hypothesis that will be tested is that via long-range electron transfer dioxygen promotes catalysis by generating the +3 oxidation state on the active-site Mn ion situated at the N-terminal end, which in turn drives the reaction. The proposed work will elucidate how proteins tune and utilize the redox potential of mono-nuclear Mn centers for catalysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits: Oxalate Decarboxylase (OxDC) is an enzyme that occurs primarily in fungi and soil bacteria. It catalyzes the heterolytic cleavage of the environmental toxin oxalic acid into carbon dioxide and formate. A single protein subunit of OxDC is composed of two so-called cupin (from Latin cupa = barrel) motifs, each containing a Mn(II) ion, both of which are necessary for activity. Six of these subunits cluster together into a dimer of trimer as the fundamental quaternary structure in which the enzyme is normally found. The work in this project has led to a new mechanistic proposal for the catalytic mechanism which provides a deeper understanding of how the enzyme functions. It takes into account the fact that both Mn ions are catalytically relevant and that a long-range electron transfer pathway exists between them, albeit across subunit boundaries.

Using theoretical electron hole hopping calculations on the enzyme structure in combination with site-directed mutagenesis of two tryptophans (W96 and W274), a catalytically relevant long-range electron transfer pathway was discovered between the N-terminal Mn ion in one subunit and the C-terminal Mn ion in a neighboring subunit. W96 and W274 form a so-called π-stacked pair where the molecular planes are in close proximity and oriented almost parallel to each other. When either W96 or W274 is replaced with phenylalanine, electron transfer through this pair shuts down and is rewired through one or two auxiliary tryptophans with a concomitant reduction in enzyme activity by approximately an order of magnitude. This is due to the fact that phenylalanine is not redox-active and therefore shuts down the long-range electron transfer. Replacement of W96 or W274 with tyrosine rescues activity because tyrosine is redox-active and has a similar standard reduction potential as tryptophan. Crystal structures of the W96 mutant proteins provided clear evidence that the changes in activity were due to the electronic properties of these amino acids since the overall structure remained conserved. When the unnatural amino-acid 5-hydroxytryptophan (5-HTP) is inserted for either W96 or W274, electron transfer also shuts down and catalytic activity is suppressed. However, in this case 5-HTP acts as a sink for the electron hole and generates a neutral persistent radical which was observed and characterized by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR). The unusual linewidth of this radical’s EPR spectrum could be explained with the help of density functional theory (DFT) calculations which revealed significant exchange coupling between the unpaired electron spin on the radical and the high-spin Mn(II) ions in close proximity. Taken together, these results provide the basis for the new mechanistic scheme for catalysis where Mn(III) is generated after oxalate binds to the N-terminal Mn, the so-called active site, via electron transfer to the C-terminal Mn on the neighboring subunit. It strongly suggests that the C-terminal Mn is the place where oxygen binds to provide the terminus of the electron transfer step. Mn(III) at the N-terminal binding site is necessary for the first oxidative step in breaking down oxalate.

Another open question about the enzyme mechanism was resolved using electron nuclear double resonance (ENDOR) on oxalate-bound Mn(II) at the N-terminal site. 13C ENDOR with isotopically labeled oxalate revealed the binding pose of this molecule as side-ways bidentate, i.e., binding with two cis-oriented oxygen atoms, correcting a long-standing hypothesis of monodentate binding in the literature. Theoretical calculations with DFT confirmed that the bidentate binding pose is lower in energy than the monodentate alternative. The project has contributed to a deeper understanding of the catalytic mechanism of OxDC reconciling a number of earlier observations into a coherent picture and providing the basis for future work to use protein engineering techniques to utilize this enzyme for industrial biotechnological processes.

Broader Impacts: The project has supported the work of four graduate students and thirty undergraduate students. The two senior graduate students have since graduated. One of them works in an academic post-doctoral position while the other works in industry. Both are using the skills they have acquired during their training. Fourteen of the thirty undergraduate students have since graduated with their B.S. degrees from the University of Florida. Four of them have written honors theses about their work in the PI's lab and graduated summa cum laude. The PI initiated and participated in a CURE (course based undergraduate research experience) class in his home department which is taught every spring semester since 2019 by him and 5 - 6 research faculty in order to train undergraduate freshman students in the techniques of protein engineering. Through this CURE course, fifteen undergraduate students were introduced and participated in the PI's lab on research involving OxDC.
